I think this is the same problem as bug 93343.

The ant plugins should require org.eclipse.osgi to get access to packages 
available from the boot classpath.  In this case org.apache.ant does not 
require any bundles.  Adding the following header to arg.apache.ant should fix 
the problem

Require-Bundle: org.eclipse.osgi

Thanks...this does appear to fix the problem.
Is this a new requirement...org.apache.ant has never required osgi before?

see bug 87780 for more detail ...

Short version of the story:
In OSGi R4 the delegation model changed such that all the non java.* packages 
provided by the JVM are not available for free to bundles.  In order to gain 
access to non-java.* packages from the JVM a bundle needs to either import the 
package (i.e. Import-Package: org.xml.sax) or require the system.bundle (i.e. 
Require-Bundle: org.eclipse.osgi).  The system bundle (org.eclips.osgi) will 
export all known packages provided by the JVM platform profile.

The motivation for such a change is to allow packages to be overriden from the 
JVM and class loading performance improvements.  We now only delegate to the 
boot classloader if we know the package is supposed to be provided by the JVM.

Darin, you should probably update the org.apache.lucene bundle also.  It may 
have the same issues.

Sorry, I do not own that plugin and don't even know who does :-)
I believe this should merit a general annoucement on the eclipse-dev list as 
this could possible require changes in many plugins both in and outside the 
Ecipse SDK

oops, I made the wrong assumption :)  I will send a note to the eclispe-dev 
mailing list, thanks.

I have seen nothing broken in lucene plug-in yet.  I believe Lucene engine is 
pure enough to not require anything beside java.**.
If we go with a word that all plug-ins must require osgi I will add it, 
otherwise Lucene itself still works OK.
